intro: Habracanthus hispidulus, commonly known as the rough-hairy morning glory, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of South America. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 meters, featuring hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces trumpet-shaped flowers that are usually blue or violet in color, blooming in the morning. Its seeds are enclosed in a spiral-shaped capsule, which splits open to release the seeds when mature. The plant is part of the Convolvulaceae family, known for its climbing or trailing growth habits.
